Blood rain, star jelly and crimson snow: Earth's strange phenomena.

05/03/2019

A look at some of the rarer and unusual conditions on our planet.

Image by Image: Bryant Olsen

By James Bithell

The human race constantly launches satellites, spacecraft and other objects into the atmosphere. However, sometimes the atmosphere drops stranger things back from the sky onto Earth. Blood rain, star jelly and red snow are all examples of these unusual occurrences.


Blood rain, a phenomenon where red rain appears to fall from the sky as blood, has been documented since the 8th century BC, when Homer wrote about it in his famous poem, The Iliad. Before the 17th century, the rain was thought to be actual blood, and a very bad omen, from supernatural origins.  The most famous, and one of the largest blood rain events was on 25 July- 23 September 2001 in Kerala, India. Red rain fell sporadically through this period, with yellow, green and black rain also reported. The phenomenon has happened several times since, in India and Sri Lanka, among other countries.

There have been a few suggestions as to the explanation that the rain, with experts posing different occurrences might be caused by different factors. Normal explanations include dust or other debris in the atmosphere, or even sunspots and aurorae. In Kerala, the initial reason was thought to be fallout from a meteor burst. Other hypotheses were that the colour was caused by red dust; acidic material from an eruption of a volcano or even extraterrestrial microorganisms.

The government of India then commissioned a study, which found the culprit to be airborne spores of prolific terrestrial algae. After no successful chemical tests for the presence of dissolved salts, unusual pH, or abnormal element compositions, the water was subject to energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, where it was found the particles consisted mainly of carbon and oxygen. After ruling out meteor debris, as such debris would be affected by wind changes when falling from the stratosphere, and performing to basic light microscopy it was concluded the particles resembled spores. After handing the samples over to the Tropical Botanical Garden and Research Institute, it was concluded the colour of the rain was â€œdue to the presence of a large amount of spores of a lichen forming alga belonging to the genus Trentepohliaâ€.

The most popular explanations are extraterrestrial, cosmic or paranormal in nature. These range from meteor residue to alien waste from UFOs. Much more realistic explanations have included the biological remains of amphibians, bacteria or slime mould.



These cold-loving microorganisms use this as a way to protect themselves from ultraviolet light, and as a way to create water, as the red pigment absorbs more heat than normal. This red snow has an alarming downside however, as although the melting is good for the algae, it causes the melting of the already rapidly retreating glaciers. 


All these strange phenomena are examples that the Earthâ€™s ecology is not always as predictable as we think, and even small organisms can produce some of the most unusual effects sighted. Keep these examples in mind- the next time you consider the environment to be unimportant- or boring!
